title: Africa: Will Brics Summit Confirm Rising Powers As Major Players in Development?
text:
South Africa: Fact and Fiction in Jurassic World 
What is unique and exciting about their engagement with Low Income Countries is their own very recent experience of growing out of poverty and rapidly into global super-powers, as is particularly the case of China. This experience informs their approach of "south-south-cooperation", based on mutual benefits and learning, rather than expert knowledge transfer more traditionally associated with western donors. 
New Centre for Rising Powers and Global Development based IDS 
The Centre for Rising Powers and Global Development (CRPD), launched earlier this year, builds on IDS' legacy of work on these countries, including the Asian Drivers project, the BRICS Initiative and the Rising Powers in International Development programme. 
CRPD conducts and facilitates research on: 
the impact of the BRICS and other rapidly-changing and increasingly influential middle-income countries on low-income countries 
the need for the restructuring of global development institutions and global public goods, such as the environment, food, and health 
the future of Development Studies research and training. 
Fundamental to the centre's approach, is its unique set of global networks and relationships, and its approach to mutual learning, such as developed through a Senior International Associates programme. These networks are growing, for example, on the day of the Centre's launch, IDS signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Development Research Centre of the State Council of the People's Republic of China. 
More recently, the centre has been working on the launch of a Rising Powers Young Researchers network, aimed at PhD students and early career researchers 
Rising Powers in International Development Eldis Resource Guide - 1,000s of free resources 
This guide, curated by the Eldis editorial team based at IDS, shares over 1,100 free resources on rising powers in international development, curated from organisations across the world, but in particular from the global South. Each document is abstracted, so readers can quickly get a sense of whether or not it's relevant to their needs. 
Eldis is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year, and its database contains over 40,000 summaries and document links. Readers can contribute their own work, as well as subscribe to regular email updates. Additionally, Eldis data for use on other information platforms through an open API. Africa
